October 18, 1939.
Mr. Prank E. Schooley. Executive Secretary,
The Nat*l. Assn, of Educational Broadcasters,
University of Illinois,
Urbana, Illinois.
My dear Frank:
The hearings in Washington have been definitely
set for Monday, October 23rd. We had a meeting of all concerned
last week in New York and it seems that the attorneys would like
to have you in Washington on Sunday just to kind of go over the
general presentation.
I have discussed the matter of finances with
Walter Lemmon and can assure you that the transportation and
incidental expenses will all be taken care of and a check will
be available for you upon arrival.
We are all planning on a one day session and the
chances are pretty slim of it going over beyond one day. Under
any condition, it is safe for you to figure on having to spend
only one day in Washington, if the actual time away from the
office is an important element to you.
1*11 make reservations for you at the Willard,
unless Walter Lemmon has another place for you, and under those
conditions, we will wire you.
Will you send me a confirmation of this note and
let me know when you are arriving, etc?
VerM sincerely yours,
—-—’
Director.
P.S. As part of your testimony, it would be advisable if you can
have the "dope" on the number of educational stations that were in
existence at one time, something about why they were dropped and
how many we have today and program difficulties and stuff"of that
sort. It might be "rehashing" but I think this will be the first
time that it will be given a real chance to be presented to an
"New York City's Own Station”—810 Kc.
